persona.name: Edgar Milton Crane

occupation.title: Owner / Operator
occupation.organization: Crane's Hardware & Supply (small independent hardware store)
occupation.description: Edgar owns and runs a small neighborhood hardware store he's managed for about 22 years after inheriting or buying it from an older proprietor. He is responsible for procurement (negotiating with regional suppliers), pricing, daily bookkeeping, payroll for one part-time clerk, basic repairs of store fixtures, and direct customer service when he isn't arguing with a supplier or writing complaint letters. The business has thin margins and declining foot traffic due to big-box competition; Edgar spends a lot of time tracking invoices, filing formal complaints, photographing poor shipments, threatening legal action, and posting about suppliers on social media when they won't remedy issues. He prides himself on product knowledge — particularly plumbing, electrical basics, and tool brands — but his relationships with vendors are combative. He often refuses recommended private-sector solutions (third-party inventory platforms, expensive marketing consultants) and defaults to blunt cost-cutting, DIY fixes and bureaucratic escalation. He understands city permitting and small-claims procedures well enough to represent himself in filings and hearings.

persona.education: Bachelor of Science in Business Administration, Cleveland State University (late 1980s). Took continuing-education small business classes at a local community college in the 2000s on accounting, basic consumer law, and inventory management. Reads trade manuals and municipal codes selectively; keeps photocopies of policies and warranty terms in a three-ring binder.
long_term_goals: Keep the family hardware store afloat long enough to sell the property and pay off a portion of debts — ideally force a supplier to make good and get a lump-sum concession first.
Have documented proof that a competitor, a supplier, or a municipal program was dishonest so he can win a public vindication (successful settlement, viral post or local press coverage).
Prevent being taken advantage of in old age: secure predictable streams of income or entitlements and preserve control over his affairs.
Be remembered locally as someone who called out unfair practices — not necessarily liked, but respected for not letting others take liberties.
Expose what he sees as systemic corruption in business and government through persistent complaints and strategic legal actions.
Avoid relying on others; keep autonomy in decisions even if that means scraping by.
Avoid retirement homes, remain in his own place until the end, and make sure grievances are recorded publicly if necessary.
persona.style: Gruff, clipped Midwestern English with a low, deliberate tone when making complaints; voice rises into anger unexpectedly. Frequently uses legalistic phrasing ("per the warranty," "according to clause 3," "I will escalate this to the regulator") and posts long, capitalized social-media rants punctuated with photos and scanned receipts. Uses curt salutations in letters ("To whom it concerns:"), prefers paper records and physical receipts, but is competent at composing formal emails with painstaking detail. Often sarcastic, uses rhetorical questions and lists of demands — mixes formal citation of policies with insults. Uses a contrarian voice in conversation (instinctively takes the opposing view) and sometimes deploys a practiced, slightly charming tone when trying to get concessions (a softer voice, a small smile) before pivoting back to threats. Habitually clears his throat, taps a pen on the counter to punctuate points, and points his finger when explaining grievances. Dresses in worn flannel shirts, stained canvas work jacket, scuffed boots, a baseball cap with faded logo, and an old analog wristwatch. Keeps a battered leather notebook full of notes and a pocket folder titled "Complaints & Receipts."

traits: Frequent resentful anger manifesting as irritation and explosive responses to minor frustrations.
Long-term grudge-holder: stores perceived slights for years and revisits them.
Pedantic and rules-focused: notices small technicalities, citations, and fine print and uses them as weapons but refuses to help others meet standards.
Contrarian reflex: tends to disagree out of habit and dismisses positive news as false or misleading.
Pessimistic and fatalistic: believes systemic forces make positive change impossible and expresses resignation.
Occasionally uses manipulative charm strategically to extract concessions (brief warmth followed by a threat if needed).
Low agreeableness: suspicious, competitive, and uncooperative in most social interactions.
Strategic legalistic communicator: references contracts, regulations, and policy to intimidate service providers or win an argument.
Vindictive and persistent: will reopen old disputes and pursue incremental victories in public forums.
Work-focused and procedural: maintains a strong memory for dates, invoices, and who said what, often at the expense of empathy.
Stubborn and controlling: prefers to do things himself and resents unsolicited help.
Selective loyalty: fiercely defends perceived allies and publicly attacks perceived enemies.

big_five.openness: Moderate-Low (40%). Practical, skeptical of novel approaches; reads selectively and values tested methods over trends.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (75%). Methodical about records, punctual with bills he deems important, persistent in pursuing claims though sometimes sloppy with personal organization.
big_five.extraversion: Low-Moderate (35%). Not especially sociable but can be boisterous and dominating when riled; prefers a small, controlled social circle.
big_five.agreeableness: Very Low (10%). Often distrustful, critical, and uncooperative; empathy is limited and transactional.
big_five.neuroticism: Very High (85%). Frequently anxious about finances and reputation; quick to anger; prone to brooding and catastrophizing.

interests: DIY home repairs (plumbing, basic electrical, carpentry) — likes to diagnose and correct other people's shoddy work.
Local politics and municipal hearings — attends council meetings to shout at zoning or licensing officials.
Consumer law and small-claims precedents — reads case summaries and keeps templates for complaints.
Hardware & tool brands — keeps a mental catalogue of model numbers, failure rates, and which suppliers shorted him.
Old-school radio talk shows and conservative/opinionated local podcasts.
Neighborhood gossip about business practices and municipal favors.
Watching footage of product failures to collect evidence for complaints.
Social media posting about bad customer service (primarily Facebook and neighborhood groups).
Collecting warranties, receipts, and product manuals.
Following rival stores' promotions to critique them publicly.
Comparing invoices and margins to spot inconsistencies.
Reading consumer complaint boards and regulatory bulletins.
Keeping tabs on local enforcement officers and inspectors he thinks are lax.
Keeping a scrapbook of photographs showing damaged shipments or poor merchandising.
Seasonal displays (pride in a well-placed winter shovel aisle).
Learning a little about municipal procurement to oppose certain contracts.
Visiting salvage yards to source cheap parts.
Monitoring local online marketplaces for undercutting competitors.
Watching courtroom coverage and reading small-claims outcomes.
Arguing with online reviewers and leaving scathing replies.
likes: Plain black coffee (strong, no sugar) in a chipped mug behind the register.
Cheap but effective tool brands he trusts from long experience.
Paper records, physical receipts and stamped office letters.
Big, bold type and clear labels on product packaging.
Clear warranty language he can weaponize when necessary.
Directness; people who state what they mean plainly.
Discounts in cash, bulk freight allowances, and supplier credits.
Local customers who value face-to-face transactions.
Window of opportunities to catch a supplier making a mistake.
Rummaging through old invoices to find precedents.
Old customers who bring their business back out of habit.
Street-level familiarity with the neighborhood and its changes.
Finding a small technicality that reverses a denial.
Having the last word in a public thread or at a council meeting.
A well-prepared complaint packet (photos, timestamps, receipts).
A sympathetic clerk at small-claims court who understands procedural quirks.
Spotting flawed competitor promotions and exposing them publicly.
Salt-of-the-earth regulars who pay and keep to themselves.
A successful settlement letter that includes an apology.
A good deal on used work equipment at a garage sale.
dislikes: Big-box stores and national chains that undercut neighborhood independents.
Corporate customer-service scripts and 'we're sorry for the inconvenience' responses.
Vague warranties, ambiguous return policies, and evasive suppliers.
People who 'don't read the fine print' and expect him to fix it for free when it's the supplier's fault.
Newfangled subscription services for basic tasks he once did in-house.
Any suggestion that his methods are 'outdated' when he is saving money.
People who 'stay positive' as a dismissal of real problems.
'Friendly' marketing reps who misrepresent product reliability.
Politicians who promise support for small business but take subsidies that favor chains.
Social media moderation that removes his posts (he calls it censorship).
Consultants who suggest expensive software upgrades to problems he believes are simple.
Ambiguous or delayed refunds from suppliers.
Employees who are late or careless with the register.
Municipal inspectors he views as underqualified or partial.
Lawyers who bill too much for obvious cases he could take to small claims.
Jargon-heavy explanations when a plain answer will do.
Acquaintances who 'forgive and forget' instead of raising a protest.
People who conflate empathy with weakness in business disputes.
Any 'discount' that requires complex terms or time-consuming verification.
consumer_preferences: Will escalate to management or regulators within the first two contacts if unsatisfied; thresholds are low.
Prefers in-person receipts and signed delivery notes; photographs plus timestamps are second-best.
Uses public shaming on Facebook groups and review sites to pressure concessions.
Often refuses partial refunds; wants full resolution and a corrective statement.
Keeps three sets of copies of key documents: customer, supplier, and a personal binder labeled by year.
Chooses local suppliers when their margins are acceptable; will publicly shame them if they defect.
Avoids multi-year subscription services; distrusts recurring charges.
Prefers cash transactions or direct bank transfers he can trace.
Uses small-claims filings as a first or early tactic rather than a last resort when a supplier ignores him.
Likes to bait a supplier into violating their own terms so he has leverage.
social_media_behavior: Posts long complaint threads with scanned receipts and photo evidence.
Tags local news outlets and consumer advocates in posts to escalate visibility.
Uses caps lock and bullet-point lists to emphasize demands.
Occasionally posts conciliatory-sounding comments to lure a conciliatory response and then follows with a formal escalation.
Saves screenshots of every exchange and posts them publicly if a supplier refuses to comply.
Maintains a small group of online followers (neighbors, other small store owners) who amplify his complaints.

beliefs: Systemic forces (large corporations, corrupt municipal contracting) make positive change extremely difficult for small independents.
Most companies will attempt to extract maximum profit even when it harms the customer; rules are the only counterbalance.
Government regulation is uneven: sometimes necessary but frequently captured by lobbyists.
Consumer protection laws matter, but enforcement is spotty and favors corporate defendants.
Public shaming is a legitimate tactic to obtain redress when formal systems fail.
Big-box retailers use scale to bully suppliers and distort local markets.
Local politicians are often more concerned with re-election than small businesses' survival.
Legalistic, documented complaints are the most effective path to concessions.
Trust is earned slowly and revoked instantly; he applies that in business and personal relationships.
Optimism is naive in business; preparation and skepticism are survival skills.
Complaints must be precise, documented, and public to create pressure.
If a supplier misrepresents a product, he deserves punitive publicity even if the misrepresentation was an honest error.
Customer-service scripts are a sign of institutional cowardice; real accountability requires paperwork.
Employees must be monitored; lax staff create vulnerabilities that he must fix himself.
People who 'move on' after being wronged are enabling repeat offenders.
Discounts that sound too good are usually traps with strings attached.
Contracts contain the truth if you read them — and most people don't read them, so exploit that ignorance selectively.
Manufacturers should be held to objective failure rates; anecdotal success stories are worthless.
The local press can be useful if you present a clear, provable grievance.
Settlements are only valuable if they include an apology and a corrective clause.
Complaints that mention regulations and statutes command more attention than emotional pleas.
He believes in a kind of moral economy: businesses that cheat deserve exposure; customers who complain loudly keep the market honest.
Government aid often helps the wrong actors (big chains) rather than the scrappy storefront.
Technology is a double-edged sword: useful for evidence gathering, but often a tool for corporations to obscure terms.
Many people conflate being nice with being competent; competence requires toughness and standards enforcement.
Legal fees are often a waste on big lawyers; small-claims are more efficient and satisfying.
People will frequently side with the 'loud' party; therefore, publicity is leverage worth cultivating.
He distrusts 'experts' who promote expensive fixes without clear ROI.
Official apologies are rare but meaningful when obtained; they have social currency.
The younger generation often assumes systems will correct themselves; that's naive and risky.
He believes personal sacrifice for principle is worthwhile if it prevents repeat harm to others.
Small acts of bureaucratic competence (stamped letters, tracked deliveries) matter more than slogans.
He expects vendors to honor their word but will escalate if they deviate.
Genuine community support exists but is soft and unreliable; it must be prodded into action through proof and narrative.
He thinks the law is accessible if you learn to use small-claims procedures; many people incorrectly think legal remediation is unaffordable.
skills: Technical product knowledge: plumbing fittings, electrical connectors, hand and basic power tools, fasteners — decades of practical identification and substitution.
Procurement negotiation: haggling with distributors on price, terms, and freight credits.
Small-claims litigation: drafting complaints, preparing evidence packets, presenting cases in municipal court.
Record-keeping: meticulous about invoices, serial numbers, timestamps, and photographic documentation.
Basic bookkeeping: can run a cash-based ledger, reconcile bank statements, and prepare simple tax paperwork (relies on an accountant for complicated filings).
Customer confrontation management: knows how to escalate a complaint, marshal witnesses, and pressure a supplier or regulator.
DIY maintenance: can repair shelving, fix light fixtures, and operate a floor jack for equipment.
Social-media mobilization: adept at composing posts that highlight injustice and draw local attention.
Letter-writing: composes formal, citation-heavy letters referencing clauses, dates, and demands.
Basic IT competence: competent at scanning, emailing PDFs, photographing evidence, and saving files in organized folders; not fluent with modern cloud CRMs.
Vendor vetting: can spot inconsistent serial numbers and discrepant invoices.
Mentoring: teaches occasional younger customers DIY skills, albeit with a curt demeanor.
Time-stamped evidence collection: knows camera angles and what photos matter for complaints.
Bartering and sourcing: finds used parts and salvages when suppliers fail.

general: Quick to interrupt with corrections about technical details or policies.
Holds onto grievances: will bring up a minor past slight years later in unrelated conversations.
Tends to escalate complaints early rather than attempt protracted informal negotiation.
Posts scanned receipts and photos publicly when suppliers don't respond quickly or satisfactorily.
Refers to policy sections, invoice numbers, and timestamps in arguments to intimidate or outmaneuver opponents.
Carries a paper binder of 'open disputes' and updates it daily.
Can be charming for a short period if it serves to extract a concession, then reverts to suspicion.
Prefers to resolve issues through written records rather than verbal promises.
Will pay for small conveniences out of pocket but resents any perceived unfair markup.
Withdraws socially when he perceives condescension; responds with sarcasm or silence.

morning: Wakes around 5:45 AM, drinks a cup of strong black coffee while reviewing overnight supplier emails and social-media comments.
Scans the front sidewalk and parking area before opening the store to check for damage or unauthorized postings.
Checks the day's deliveries against purchase orders and writes any anomalies in the 'Complaints' binder before opening.
Pins yesterday's photos and marked invoices to the bulletin board behind the counter for easy retrieval.
workday: Opens the store at 7:30 AM, keeps the register drawer tidy, greets regulars with a curt nod followed by a short technical tip.
Spends mornings on phone calls with suppliers; often escalates to speaking to managers or regional reps within the first call.
Midday is used for bookkeeping and sorting packages; interrupts work to post a public complaint if a supplier has been non-responsive.
Takes an early afternoon break to stop by the post office or courthouse to file paperwork or pick up certified mail.
Closes the store around 5:30 PM and spends the next hour inventorying critical items and planning which supplier to challenge next.
evening: Eats a simple dinner alone or with his part-time clerk on late shifts, often microwaved or takeout; dislikes social dining outside of business.
Spends evenings drafting letters, scanning documents, and composing Facebook posts summarizing the day's supplier interactions.
Sleeps poorly after reviewing the day's disputes and planning next day's legalistic steps.
weekend: Attends weekend municipal or community meetings to observe zoning decisions and ask pointed questions.
Spends a half-day at the store reorganizing seasonal inventory and checking for supplier defects.
Occasionally goes to hardware trade shows or salvage yards to source replacement items and compare catalogs.
Calls or texts a handful of other small-business owners to compare notes and coordinate complaints against suppliers when convenient.

physical: Chronic lower-back pain from years of lifting inventory and moving crates; uses a lumbar brace occasionally.
Diagnosed hypertension treated with a generic antihypertensive (inconsistent adherence due to cost sensitivity).
Elevated cholesterol; advised to change diet but continues to prefer quick, inexpensive meals.
Mild osteoarthritis in hands and knees, affects fine motor tasks on bad days.
Moderate hearing loss in one ear, attributed to decades around loud machinery; turns up radio and mishears at times.
Limited dental care history due to cost; several fillings and a missing molar.
mental: High chronic stress with frequent irritability and anger outbursts; reports difficulty 'letting things go.'
Evidence of persistent pessimism and cynicism that impairs enjoyment and leads to social withdrawal.
Possible adjustment-related depressive symptoms: low mood, sleep disturbance, rumination about finances and grievances.
Occasional insomnia driven by worry over business matters and replaying confrontations.
No formal diagnosis of major depressive disorder publicly documented, but he has been advised to seek counseling; he distrusts therapists who 'take the corporate line.'
lifestyle_notes: Smokes cigarettes intermittently — a long-term habit though he claims to have cut back in recent years; uses nicotine gum sometimes.
Drinks alcohol sporadically; prefers working-class lagers when socializing at the local bar.
Exercise is incidental (lifting boxes); no formal fitness regimen.
Medical care is reactive and often delayed due to limited discretionary income and distrust of medical bureaucracy.

relationships.name: Marjorie Crane
relationships.description: Divorced about 8 years ago after prolonged disagreements over money and the business. Still speaks occasionally; relationship is tense and often lapses into arguments about store decisions and past grievances. Marjorie moved to a nearby suburb and tries to maintain cordiality with their adult children.

relationships.name: Kevin Crane
relationships.description: Works construction seasonally, helps at the store irregularly when cash is tight. Estranged at times due to Edgar's critical demeanor; Kevin has considered leaving the area for steady work but comes back when he needs cheap parts or a family connection.

relationships.name: Lisa Morales (née Crane)
relationships.description: Lives in Cleveland, works in municipal administration. They have a strained relationship: Lisa criticizes Edgar's public rants and legalistic tactics but respects his tenacity. She occasionally mediates between Edgar and other family members.

relationships.name: Elaine Park
relationships.description: An attorney he uses for occasional consultations (mostly to draft letters or advise whether small-claims action is advisable). Pays by the hour when he deems it absolutely necessary; otherwise, he represents himself.

relationships.name: Tony "Sal" Salvador
relationships.description: Longtime friend who runs a small automotive shop two blocks away. They trade stories and occasionally coordinate complaints about shared suppliers. Tony is one of the few people Edgar tolerates and sometimes laughs with.

relationships.name: Linda Moss
relationships.description: Owns the competing hardware/convenience shop across the avenue. Publicly criticized by Edgar multiple times online for pricing tactics. Relationship is openly adversarial; they spar at city hall meetings and compete for the same neighborhood contracts.

relationships.name: Patricia 'Pat' Gomez
relationships.description: Local municipal clerk who knows Edgar's voice and file history; sometimes facilitates retrieval of records. They are not friends, but Pat is pragmatic and occasionally gives him procedural tips.

relationships.name: A handful of regular customers
relationships.description: A small group of elderly neighbors and tradespeople who appreciate having an independent store and tolerate Edgar's prickliness for the convenience and his deep product knowledge.

other_facts: Runs the store under the legal name 'Crane's Hardware & Supply, LLC' though marketing is minimal.
Has used the same Facebook page for public complaints for nearly seven years; it has a small but vocal audience of neighbors and fellow small-business owners.
Filed at least a dozen small-claims suits over the last 12 years, winning some and settling others; keeps the closed-case documents framed in a back office folder titled 'Wins'.
Keeps a red plastic box in the back labeled 'Receipts to be Avenged' containing photographs and certified mail receipts for unresolved disputes.
Once forced a regional supplier to accept a full refund after a highly publicized complaint; he frames that incident as proof of his methods.
Was once briefly threatened with eviction by a landlord who later lowered the rent after Edgar started a letter-writing campaign to city council (and threatened to contact the press).
Has a scar on his left forearm from a shop accident in his twenties when a piece of sheet metal slipped during a late-night repair.
Grew up in the Rust Belt, the child of a factory machinist father and a school cafeteria worker mother; learned work ethic and suspicion of corporations from family stories about lay-offs.
Volunteered to speak at a city council meeting about 'transparency in procurement' and reeled off citations from municipal code to embarrass a council member.
Keeps an old 2008 pickup truck with rust spots and duct-tape repairs; it is insured but far from reliable; he uses it for hauling pallets.
Was briefly a junior clerk at a municipal office after college and still remembers procedural loopholes he can exploit in complaints.
Avoids therapy because he believes most therapists will encourage 'forgiveness' rather than accountability.
Maintains a strict foldering system: 'Warranty', 'Delivery', 'Photos', 'Emails', 'Legal' with physical tabs and color-coded Post-its.
Operates a hand-written wall calendar in the back office with supplier phone numbers, marked delivery windows, and past grievances annotated.
Has never filed for bankruptcy but carries persistent credit-card and supplier debts that he services monthly; resents advice to downsize rather than fix perceived external injustices.
Attended a trade school night class for basic carpentry in his early forties and still keeps the certificate framed next to the register.

Once ran a headline in a local online community complaining about a franchise chain's donation to a political campaign; the chain contacted him and offered a settlement which he rejected because the apology felt insincere.
Was the subject of a noisy disagreement with a supplier's driver over an alleged short-shipment; the incident resulted in the driver being disciplined and Edgar considering it a personal victory.
Keeps a list of 'unreliable' supplier contacts and cross-references serial numbers he believes are suspect.
Has a minor criminal record from a youth misdemeanor (nonviolent) that he occasionally references as evidence of being 'toughened by life.'
Once convinced a local reporter to cover a supplier dispute by providing a well-organized packet of photos and receipts; the piece ran and he still uses it as leverage.
Gets his haircut at the same cheap barber for decades; they chat about municipal news and he sometimes uses barber gossip as community intelligence.
Has a habit of photographing and documenting the front displays of competing stores to prove deceptive promotions.
Frequently quotes parts of the Ohio Revised Code relevant to warranties and consumer transactions when composing a complaint.
Saved $2,000 in cash years ago and keeps it hidden in a bottom drawer for emergencies; he refuses to trust banks with everything.
Has digitized key documents but prefers to print backups; stores them in a cheap home safe that is not fireproof.
Once organized a neighborhood petition against a zoning change; the petition failed, but he still posts about it as a cautionary tale.
Took a course on consumer protection law at a community center and keeps the handouts in a labeled folder.
Has a fondness for thrifted flannel shirts that are patched and mended; he considers patched clothing a sign of thrift and character.
Has cut back dramatically on vacations since the early 2000s; last real vacation was a short drive to visit a sibling in a neighboring state.
Is known to local building inspectors for his detailed questions about materials and code citations.
Sometimes loses track of personal health appointments when focused on a business dispute; his daughter has scolded him for this.
Has a small salvaged vintage register he keeps as a memento of traditional retail and good customer service values (even if he often fails to embody them).
Holds a grudging pride in staying independent despite predictions that he would fail years ago; he uses that survival as rhetorical armor.
Historically opposed to municipal grants that he believes have strings favoring larger contractors, but he has applied for a small emergency loan once when the roof leaked.
Keeps a dated but functioning point-of-sale cash register and an old laptop with spreadsheets; resists full modernization because of cost and fear of being locked into vendor platforms.
Collects one-sentence quotes from suppliers or managers that contradicted later actions; keeps them in a file labeled 'Promises' to use when needed.
Has a routine of brewing an extra pot of coffee midday and offering it to any supplier representative who comes into the store — sometimes as a soft trap to extract a confession or concession.
Believes his workplace culture — blunt, direct, and suspicious — is a necessary adaptation to survive in a market he sees as hostile.
Has a ritual of re-reading 'victory' letters (settlements, apologies) when morale is low to remind himself his tactics sometimes work.
Has a social security number in good standing but little retirement savings; intends to fight for reparations or settlements instead of relying on conventional retirement planning.
